title: I Cried While Playing League
body:
I am so tired of the toxicity in this sad excuse of a "community." Out of all the games I've played in my life, the people here are the absolute worst. I started playing League a few years ago, but I ended up leaving the game because I was flamed too often for "sucking" or "feeding." I've been back for not even a month, and I've experienced this tenfold. I already want to quit again, and I hate it because I absolutely enjoy the gameplay. I've been told to kill myself, commit suicide, uninstall League, never play said champ again, and endless colorful insults that I wish to not think about. 

I've had two or three games so far this past month (one of which happened today) where the abuse was so bad to the point where I actually cried. I was trying out Syndra today in a non-ranked game, and I was laning against someone who clearly REALLY knew how to play Yasuo (quite aggressively at that). Ended up dying a few times and then was focused by the enemy jungler and mid laner because I was so far behind. I made it clear as day that I was learning the champ. I also explained that I'd practiced the champ in bot games, read guides, and wanted to try her out in PVP. But this didn't stop people from acting like complete jerks. I was bashed so often and so early to the point where I was considering leaving the game, because at that point, I would have rather been reported and banned for leaving the game than be bullied anymore. I didn't discover the mute button until after that game, but that's beside the point. 

I do everything I know to do deal with toxicity — report, (now) mute, not adding fuel to the fire, taking breaks, finding other games, or all of those. I don't know how exactly how many players I've reported for bad behavior — maybe ~50 so far. Only 2 have been banned. 

I am aggravated. And sick of this. I don't know how else to deal with it, other than what I'm doing now.

that support brings shame to the role then. I am a bronze 5 support main but I still like to be as nice as possible. If he/she saw you were having trouble he/she should have offered 'emotional' support, advice on combos and roamed mid inbetween botlane backs. Support is not just about warding and peeling. You also have 'support' the morale of the team and leave no man(or woman) behind.

Even then there is no reason to be toxic to someone especially in normals if they are trying their best and are friendly. If you are getting dived alot though as a midlane immobile mage it's excusable to rush a tank/cdr item like zhonias or RoA+frozen heart since this will stop the dives if you back when below 30% hp and gives you a bit more time to do damage, it's especially useful due to syndra's high damage output and cc so you can still do alright with a tank item in your kit since you aren't pure damage.

on another note if you just want to play normals try building a friends list of players around your level who are friendly and queue with them. Toxic players are almost always toxic and nice players are generally nice (maybe on a bad day if you try exhaust+ignite soraka jungle they might get upset). I am so sorry for your bad experience and I think it's a shame that people were mean to you when you were trying your best.

I went through this stage of absolute frustration and got completely disgusted with the game. Thing that helped me a lot was /mute all as soon as I got into the game and I cannot believe how much this helped. Eventually I stopped doing this and whenever I had someone in my game that made me want to type something in chat that wasn't game related I just mute them immediately. 

It also helped me to look at the game differently by not playing to win but to play to have fun. There is definitely a fine line with this and you should still remember the basics of building properly and not making stupid decisions. You still play to win but you have to remember the fun aspects first. When I did this I started to win more and have a good time. 

Number one thing I would do is to focus on mastering one thing at a time. First I'd find the champion styles that suit you e.g. I play well with AP mages vel'koz, lux, orianna etc etc. I can pick up t hose t types of champions and do better on those then anything else because it comes naturally. Second focus on not dying and not greeding kills. It is so much more important not to die then it is to get kills. Number three is just to have map awareness and try and help your team as much as possible by ganking  and being there for them if they're caught out. But remember not to die int he process of trying to help them. Overall employing these things will make League less stressful :)

It's not the game, or the game's community.

It's the internet as a whole.

Over the years there have been far too many psychological studies on how humans interact in an anonymous environment to count, and they all say the same thing.
When you are safe thanks to anonymity you will not care what other people think of you, and wont try to keep up the appearance of being a "nice person" like everyone does out in the real world.

The "toxicity" is not League of Legends, it's not any game, it's the anonymous environment in which you are interaction.
It doesn't matter where you go, it will always be the exact same.
Honestly if you find yourself crying over a match of LoL, you shouldn't be on the internet at all.
As much as I want to see people banned quicker and more harshly for breaking any game's rules/ToS, you shouldn't become upset by it to begin with.

It's as bad as the spoiled American white girls and their SJW neckbeard slaves whining that we need "safe spaces".
No we don't. And we NEVER will need them.

But then again, I have a thick skin.
I was bullied so badly in school that every councilor that I had to visit was genuinely surprised that I hadn't committed suicide when other's my age had done so over less.
So maybe I'm a jaded arsehole with skin that's too thick.

Closing note: Get a thicker skin or never participate in an anonymous environment.
